content.description: Climb a couple bulges to a right angling ramp. Travel up the ramp for a bit then head straight up the short face. The route ends with classic slab moves. Good warm up and beginner lead.
content.location: Start just left of the large right angling crack with a cave/pod at the bottom. Be careful of standing too close to the edge as the dirt is disappearing fast.

content.description: After a shared start with the previous route cut right up the right trending fetchers. Clip a bolt right on the lip before climbing straight up past the roofs and rap back around left to the anchor. A few slings will cut down on rope drag.
content.location: This is the far right route located at Weekender Wall.  It may be a challenge to not fall off the belay ledge due to erosion.

content.description: Truth of the Matter starts just right of the detached boulder.  The first bolt is located 14' off the ground.  Climb straight up past a light colored bulge of amazing textured dishes and jams.  Keep going up past two small bulges and on to the anchor.
content.location: Walk or jump past the eroded section of trail to the steep white wall packed with routes. Truth of the Matter shares an anchor with Last Rage and starts on the right side of a detached boulder.

content.description: This route starts on white rock with the first bolt being 9 feet up on a slight bulge.  Climb into a small concave fetcher.  Clip three has bail tat on it.  Pull an overhanging bulge and crossing left over the ledge to gain the upper section of wall.  Clip a rap bolt on you way to the large, overhanging upper crux.  The chain anchors are hanging over the lip of the roof.
content.location: This climb is located just right of the large, washed out section of hill side at the base of the wall.  Try and not fall down the hill side during the approach or belay.

content.description: Jungle your way up vegetated and loose rock to the obvious right facing corner. Climb the corner on a finger/hand crack formed by an enormous detached flake that is magically frictioned to the wall. Scary!

Onomatopoeia has a black hanger located 11' off the ground.  Climb pumpy moves straight up the face past a slightly overhanging bulge.  More stainless steel and black painted hangers will get you to the anchor 40' up the wall.
content.location: Onomatopoeia is located in a bundle of hard routes packed onto the right side of the crag.

content.description: A fantastic short climb. Start in a small alcove and pull bouldery moves to a short face. Crimp to the anchors on fantastic stone. Very well protected.
content.location: First climb along the trail, nice cleared belay spot.

content.description: Not Worth The Trouble starts on the 45 degree, right trending squeeze crack.  Follow this on gear through the off width section and all the way up to the anchor on Onomatopoeia.
content.location: This route is located in the middle of the main Weekender Wall area.  The belay was at a ledge that has now been eroded all the way up the the rock face.

content.description: Not Named starts above an eroded section 5' left of an off width. Small gear can be used to protect the start. The first bolt is located 10' up after an overhanging bulge.  Pull onto the vertical face and continue up white colored, excellent rock to another small overhang.  The anchor is 40' off the ground.
content.location: This is the second from the last route on the left end of the crag.

content.description: Last Rage starts 5' to the right of Truth of the Matter.  The first bolt is 10' up in between two cracks that could take good gear.  Grab good holds, cracks and underclings to get to an alcove.  The second bolt is past a steep lip.  Pull hard crux moves and fight up more steep rock to the anchor.
content.location: Walk or jump past the eroded section of trail to the steep white wall packed with routes.  Last Rage climbs throught the small roof in the middle of the wall.

content.description: The other wall at Ravine Lake, this cliff has a little of everything from a 5.9 trad climb to 5.12 sport, all packed into a small section of good rock. The wall receives sun all day and dries fast after the rain. The rock is similar to other climbing areas in the Matanuska  Valley and consists of a gritty and sometimes crumbly igneous intrusion. This area is suffering from erosion so pay attention to what you stand on and where you walk. DO NOT travel up either scree/dirt gullies!
